results.title: Meeting in session
results.creator_credit: Josef Bohmer and Columbia University Teahcer's College Bureau of Publications
results.brief_description: Glimpses of a variety of meetings - a school faculty, a high school committee, a business men’s session, a committee of nurses - illustrate the fact that most of us work in groups from time to time. Two contrasting session are presented, as a small group of nurses attempts to solve the problem of adequate staffing for the hospital four to twelve shift. In each meeting the problem and the participants are the same. The differences are in general approach, attitude displayed, techniques used and results achieved. In the first meeting participants enact negative roles characteristic of individuals intent on their own feelings and problems. The supervisor is an impatient administrator; head nurses demand rigid interpretation of present rules. In the second meeting nurses assume the roles of co-operative group members interested in desirable solutions and sympathetically aware of each other’s feelings. Each member contributes, and her ideas receive thoughtful consideration. At the end the nurse-recorder sums up suggestions, and each person volunteers for work on one or more specific proposals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Josef Bohmer and Columbia University Teahcer’s College Bureau of Publications

results.title: The Meeting
results.creator_credit: Morten Parker, John Howe and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A discussion film designed to raise questions about how much support an elected group should be entitled to expect from its electorate. At a meeting of a community group, a committee, delegated to choose a play to be staged, makes its choice known. A split occurs when some disagree and it seems that the committee may be overruled.

results.title: Medieval society
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley and Gateway Film Productions
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of 14th century life in England by showing the work and responsibilities of a range of medieval people. Discusses the roles of the King, the church, the barons and the tenants.

results.title: Mediaeval monastery
results.brief_description: The general work and daily routine of monks in a medieval monastery. Stresses the importance of monasticism in the Middle Ages, distinguishes four main orders. Ground plan of typical monastery; uses of various domestic buildings illustrated by means of superimposed models. Also includes a day in the affairs of Buckfast Abbey, a modern monastery where the ancient rules of the Benedictine Order are observed.

results.title: The Medieval mind
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: An introduction to the unique character of the ‘medieval mind’. The film explains how medieval thought was fraught with tension and conflict and contrasts its world view with that of more recent times. Some of the conflicts within the Church are discussed and come medieval art, architecture and iconography is surveyed.

results.title: Medieval manor (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Oscar Sams, Sidney Painter and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains the origin of the feudal system and the benefits which it offered to both lord and serf. Recreates phases of life on a representative manor, and discusses the duties of the lord and his seneschal. The work of artisans, the importance of the three field system of agriculture, the operation of the manner court and the role of the abbey are also highlighted. Includes scenes of festivities accompanying the marriage of the lord’s son.

results.title: Mechanisms of breathing
results.brief_description: The human breathing system in operation. Animated diagrams illustrated the exchange of gases in the lungs and body tissue cells, including pathological conditions. Artificial respiration is demonstrated, and the nervous control of breathing, and factors affecting the rate and depth of respiration.

results.title: Mechanical energy and thermal energy
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description: Shows several models of both bulk motion and random motion of molecules; their interconnection as the energy of bulk motion. Demonstrates random motion and how it can average out to a smooth effect. Shows model of thermal conduction. Demonstrates a model using dry ice disc and small steel balls in which bulk mechanical energy of the disc is converted to ‘thermal’ energy of random motion of the balls. Explains the origin of the absolute temperature scale.

results.title: Max Ernst: journey into the subconscious
results.brief_description: The inner world of painter, Max Ernst, is the subject of this film. One of the principal founders of Surrealism, Max Ernst explores the nature of materials and the emotional significance of shapes to combine with his collages and nether-world canvasses.

results.title: Matter into energy (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Explains nuclear fission and fusion in terms of converting mass into energy according to Einstein’s E=MC squared formula. Employs both animation and live photography.
